Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Statistical Models and Classification of Time-Varying Shape

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This project develops nonlinear statistical models and classification procedures for time-varying shape and investigates their application to biomedical image analysis problems. In biology and medicine it is often critical to understand processes that change the shape of anatomy. For example, a neuroscientist studying the development of the infant brain would be interested in how neurodevelopment is different in healthy children versus those with Autism. An evolutionary biologist studying how a species has evolved to adapt to its environment would be interested in studying changes in the shape of bones found in the fossil record. The challenge in this modeling problem is that shape and shape variations are highly nonlinear and high-dimensional, and standard linear statistics cannot be applied. Therefore, the ability to model and understand changes in shape depends on the development of new regression models for data in nonlinear spaces. The research activities of this project include: (1) developing statistical models for dealing with time-varying shape using least-squares principles in shape manifolds, (2) investigating new classification methods for shape sequences, and (3) validating the methodology using synthetic data and testing its efficacy for neuroimaging applications in Alzheimer's disease and Autism. In addition to the significant impact to computer vision, biology, and medicine, this project is combining differential geometry, statistics, and computing within the undergraduate and graduate computer science curriculum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In biology and medicine it is often critical to understand processes that change the shape of anatomy. For example, a neuroscientist studying the development of the infant brain would be interested in how neurodevelopment is different in healthy children versus those with Autism. An oncologist developing a new cancer treatment would benefit from the ability to track the shape changes of a tumor and its surrounding anatomy to determine how a patient is responding to the treatment. The difficulty in these problems is the complex nature of shape data and shape changes, which are high-dimensional and nonlinear. Because of this traditional statistical analysis methods are not applicable to answering these questions about anatomical shape change.

To address this problem, this project developed several novel statistical methods for analyzing time-varying anatomical shape. The first class of models are regression models for shape. These regression models are applicable to data sets where there is a single measurement per person at a snapshot in time, which is known as a cross-sectional study design. These new models generalize classical statistical models, such as linear regression or polynomial regression, but now developed in nonlinear shape spaces. The second class of models are longitudinal models for shape. These longitudinal models are applicable to data sets where each person has multiple measurements over a period of time, which is known as a longitudinal study design. These longitudinal models are more powerful than simple cross-sectional regression models because they can explain the actual anatomical changes that individuals undergo.

While developing these new statistical shape models, we have worked with neuroscience researchers to apply them to neuroimaging studies (MRI). In one study, the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI), we have analyzed longitudinal neurodegeneration in Alzheimer's disease. In addition to statistically quantifying the effects of Alzheimer's disease on brain atrophy, we were able to predict which subjects at risk for Alzheimer's disease would eventually convert to have the disease, based on their neuroanatomical shape changes. In another study of Huntington's disease (PREDICT-HD), another neurodegenerative disease, we were able to link genetic risk factors for Huntington's disease with rate of atrophy in the striatum structures of the brain.
